elements.content: Five Keggin-based metal complexes, [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), were synthesized and structurally characterized. Among them, complexes 1, 2, and 4 show a cyclic structure, while complexes 3 and 5 exhibit a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure. Investigation of their structural differences reveals that anions play a key role in the formation of a cyclic structure.
elements.clean_text: Five Keggin-based metal complexes, [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), were synthesized and structurally characterized. Among them, complexes 1, 2, and 4 show a cyclic structure, while complexes 3 and 5 exhibit a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure. Investigation of their structural differences reveals that anions play a key role in the formation of a cyclic structure.

elements.content: Five Keggin-based metal complexes, [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), were synthesized and structurally characterized, showing that different types of cyclic structures could be effectively assembled on the basis of same ligand and metal ion when a labile coordination metal ion and suitable anion were used.
elements.clean_text: Five Keggin-based metal complexes, [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), were synthesized and structurally characterized, showing that different types of cyclic structures could be effectively assembled on the basis of same ligand and metal ion when a labile coordination metal ion and suitable anion were used.

elements.content: Self-assembly of cyclic structures represents an area of great interest, due to its potential application in molecular recognition, separation, and catalysis. As efficient approaches, “molecular library” (or directional-bonding), “symmetry-interaction,”1,2 and “weak-link”2 methods have provided a variety of different types of cyclic structures, such as molecular dinuclear loops, molecular triangles, squares, and even pentagons and hexagons. The different types of cyclic structures assembled so far, however, are mainly realized by a judicious choice of ligands with different angles. In contrast, the utilization of the same ligand and metal ion to construct different types of cyclic structures remains a great challenge, even though it is helpful to our understanding of the transformation between different types of cyclic structures, as well as the influence of entropy or enthalpy, the dynamics of the reaction, and the effects of an anion template11 and metalation on the assembly process. The difficulty in the assembly of different types of cyclic structures using the same ligand and metal ion is mainly attributed to the fact that different types of cyclic structures often require a different complementary pair of ligand and metal ion. For example, a molecular dinuclear loop assembled on the basis of the molecular library approach often needs a metal complex with a 60° angle between the coordinately labile sites and a rigid ligand with a 120° kink (Scheme A), while a molecular square assembled using this approach needs a metal starting material with a 90° angle between the coordination sites and a rigid linear ligand (Scheme B), or a metal complex with a 180° geometry and a ligand system with a 90° turn (Scheme C). Here we report the syntheses and crystal structures of [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), which show that different types of cyclic structures could be effectively assembled on the basis of the same ligand and metal ion when a labile coordination metal ion and a suitable anion were selected.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assembly of cyclic structures represents an area of great interest, due to its potential application in molecular recognition, separation, and catalysis. As efficient approaches, "molecular library" (or directional-bonding), "symmetry-interaction,"1,2 and "weak-link"2 methods have provided a variety of different types of cyclic structures, such as molecular dinuclear loops, molecular triangles, squares, and even pentagons and hexagons. The different types of cyclic structures assembled so far, however, are mainly realized by a judicious choice of ligands with different angles. In contrast, the utilization of the same ligand and metal ion to construct different types of cyclic structures remains a great challenge, even though it is helpful to our understanding of the transformation between different types of cyclic structures, as well as the influence of entropy or enthalpy, the dynamics of the reaction, and the effects of an anion template11 and metalation on the assembly process. The difficulty in the assembly of different types of cyclic structures using the same ligand and metal ion is mainly attributed to the fact that different types of cyclic structures often require a different complementary pair of ligand and metal ion. For example, a molecular dinuclear loop assembled on the basis of the molecular library approach often needs a metal complex with a 60° angle between the coordinately labile sites and a rigid ligand with a 120° kink (Scheme A), while a molecular square assembled using this approach needs a metal starting material with a 90° angle between the coordination sites and a rigid linear ligand (Scheme B), or a metal complex with a 180° geometry and a ligand system with a 90° turn (Scheme C). Here we report the syntheses and crystal structures of [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3PMo12O40] (1), [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (2), [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (3), [Cu4(2,4‘-bipy)4SiW12O40] (4), and [Cu3(2,4‘-bipy)4PW12O40] (5) (2,4‘-bipy = 2,4‘-bipyridine), which show that different types of cyclic structures could be effectively assembled on the basis of the same ligand and metal ion when a labile coordination metal ion and a suitable anion were selected.

elements.content: Complementary Pair of Metal Center and Ligand Required in the Construction of Molecular Dinuclear Loop (A) and Molecular Square (B, C) through the Directional-bonding Approach
elements.clean_text: 1  Complementary Pair of Metal Center and Ligand Required in the Construction of Molecular Dinuclear Loop (A) and Molecular Square (B, C) through the Directional-bonding Approach

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000−400 cm-1 with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer.

elements.content: Syntheses. (a) [Ag 3 (2,4‘-bipy) 3 PMo 12 O 40 ] (1) A mixture of H3PMo12O40 (0.31 g, 0.17 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1.0 mol L-1 NaOH, and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 160 °C and held at that temperature for 8000 min, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Brown-yellow polyhedron crystals of 1 were collected in 90.3% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 1, C30H24Ag3N6O40PMo12:  C, 13.78; H, 0.93; N, 3.21. Found:  C, 13.27; H, 1.06; N, 3.36 IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3448s, 2975m, 1636s, 1473m, 1428m, 1061s, 964s, 884s, 801s, 503w.

elements.content: (b) [Ag 4 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 SiW 12 O 40 ] (2). A mixture of H4SiW12O40 (0.36 g, 0.13 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. Pale yellow polyhedron crystals of 2 were collected in 76.2% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 2, C40H32Ag4N8O40SiW12:  C, 12.22; H, 0.82; N, 2.85. Found:  C, 11.46; H, 0.93; N, 2.76. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 2926w, 1618m, 1467w, 1410w, 1014w, 973m, 924s, 882w, 802s, 534m.

elements.content: (d) [Cu 4 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 SiW 12 O 40 ] (4). A mixture of H4SiW12O40 (0.36 g, 0.13 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 180 °C and held at that temperature for 5000 min, then cooled to 120 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Red block crystals of 4 were collected in 56.2% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 4, C40H32Cu4N8O40SiW12:  C, 12.80; H, 0.86; N, 2.99; Found:  C, 12.45; H, 0.94; N, 2.75. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3442s, 2925w, 1617s, 1473w, 1416m, 1011m, 973m, 921s, 883s, 797s, 533m..

elements.content: (e) [Cu 3 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 ]PW 12 O 40 (5). IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3446s, 1618s, 1595w, 1541w, 1471s, 1435m, 1418s, 1220w, 1079s, 977s, 893s, 814s, 667w, 596w, 521m.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Data collection for 1−5 was performed on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer at 123 K. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligand were generated geometrically (C−H, 0.96 Å) for 1−5. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes are summarized in Table .

Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligand were generated geometrically (C-H, 0.96 Å) for 1-5. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes are summarized in Table .

Description of Crystal Structures. Crystal structural analysis reveals that 1 consists of a [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit and a PMo12O40 3- anion. Two [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ units connected through the coordination of a Ag(I) cation from one [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit to a nitrogen atom from another [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit forms a unique six-membered ring as shown in Figure . Linking the adjacent six-membered rings through a pair of PMo12O40 3- anions coordinated to symmetry-related Ag2 atoms generates a ring-connected-ring one-dimensional (1D) chain as shown in Figure . To the best of our knowledge, such a unique 1D chain has not been found in a coordination polymer before. Ag−N bond distances in the linear coordination environment are 2.120(5)−2.147(6) Å; Ag−N and Ag−O bond distances in a tetrahedral coordination geometry are 2.224(5)−2.240(5) and 2.453(4)−2.500(4) Å, respectively. The bond distances of Ag−N in a linear coordination geometry being significantly shorter than those in tetrahedral coordination geometry indicates that the bond distance of metal-ligated ligand is closely related to its coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Description of Crystal Structures. Crystal structural analysis reveals that 1 consists of a [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit and a PMo12O40 3- anion. Two [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ units connected through the coordination of a Ag(I) cation from one [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit to a nitrogen atom from another [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)3]3+ unit forms a unique six-membered ring as shown in Figure . Linking the adjacent six-membered rings through a pair of PMo12O40 3- anions coordinated to symmetry-related Ag2 atoms generates a ring-connected-ring one-dimensional (1D) chain as shown in Figure . To the best of our knowledge, such a unique 1D chain has not been found in a coordination polymer before. Ag-N bond distances in the linear coordination environment are 2.120(5)-2.147(6) Å; Ag-N and Ag-O bond distances in a tetrahedral coordination geometry are 2.224(5)-2.240(5) and 2.453(4)-2.500(4) Å, respectively. The bond distances of Ag-N in a linear coordination geometry being significantly shorter than those in tetrahedral coordination geometry indicates that the bond distance of metal-ligated ligand is closely related to its coordination geometry.

elements.content: Complex 2 consists of a [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4]4+ unit and a SiW12O40 4- anion. The difference in components between 1 and 2 is unambiguously attributed to the different charge of the Keggin anion between the two complexes. Interestingly, the [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4]4+ unit exhibits a molecular square through each Ag(I) atom coordinated by two nitrogen atoms, respectively, from two 2,4‘-bipy ligands as shown in Figure . The SiW12O40 4- anion as a bridged ligand is coordinated to two Ag(I) atoms from a pair of opposite edges of the square through its two terminal oxygen atoms illustrated in Figure . Ag−N bond distances in a linear coordination environment are 2.11(3)−2.17(3) Å, while Ag−N and Ag−O bond distances in a tri-coordination geometry are 2.20(3)−2.27(3) and 2.38(3)−2.59(3) Å, respectively. Both the bond distances of Ag−N and Ag−O in 2 are comparable to those in 1.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 consists of a [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4]4+ unit and a SiW12O40 4- anion. The difference in components between 1 and  2 is unambiguously attributed to the different charge of the Keggin anion between the two complexes. Interestingly, the [Ag4(2,4‘-bipy)4]4+ unit exhibits a molecular square through each Ag(I) atom coordinated by two nitrogen atoms, respectively, from two 2,4‘-bipy ligands as shown in Figure . The SiW12O40 4- anion as a bridged ligand is coordinated to two Ag(I) atoms from a pair of opposite edges of the square through its two terminal oxygen atoms illustrated in Figure . Ag-N bond distances in a linear coordination environment are 2.11(3)-2.17(3) Å, while Ag-N and Ag-O bond distances in a tri-coordination geometry are 2.20(3)-2.27(3) and 2.38(3)-2.59(3) Å, respectively. Both the bond distances of Ag-N and Ag-O in 2 are comparable to those in 1.

elements.content: Complex 3 consists of a [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit and a PW12O40 3- anion. It was noted that, although the reaction conditions of complex 3 are very similar to those of 1, there is a significant difference in the components between the two complexes, indicating that different kinds of Keggin anions could effectively modify the host structure of the coordination polymer. In complex 3, the [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit can be viewed as a dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag2(2,4‘-bipy)2]2+ with each of its Ag(I) atoms alternately connected to [Ag(2,4‘-bipy)]+ and 2,4‘-bipy as shown in Figure . Extension of the [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit through the coordination of nitrogen atoms of the 2,4‘-bipy ligand from one unit to the Ag(I) atom of [Ag(2,4‘-bipy)]+ from the adjacent [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit generates a 1D chain as shown in Figure . Two adjacent 1D chains further linked by PW12O40 3- anions through electrostatic attraction form a two-dimensional (2D) structure as shown in Figure . Ag−N bond distances of 2.122(7) Å in a linear coordination environment are very close to those in 1 and 2. Ag−N bond distances in a tri-coordination environment are 2.212(8)−2.315(8) Å, significantly longer than those in a linear coordination geometry, further indicating that the bond distance of the metal-ligated ligand is closely related to its coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 consists of a [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit and a PW12O40 3- anion. It was noted that, although the reaction conditions of complex 3 are very similar to those of 1, there is a significant difference in the components between the two complexes, indicating that different kinds of Keggin anions could effectively modify the host structure of the coordination polymer. In complex 3, the [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit can be viewed as a dinuclear molecular loop of [Ag2(2,4‘-bipy)2]2+ with each of its Ag(I) atoms alternately connected to [Ag(2,4‘-bipy)]+ and 2,4‘-bipy as shown in Figure . Extension of the [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit through the coordination of nitrogen atoms of the 2,4‘-bipy ligand from one unit to the Ag(I) atom of [Ag(2,4‘-bipy)]+ from the adjacent [Ag3(2,4‘-bipy)4]3+ unit generates a 1D chain as shown in Figure . Two adjacent 1D chains further linked by PW12O40 3- anions through electrostatic attraction form a two-dimensional (2D) structure as shown in Figure . Ag-N bond distances of 2.122(7) Å in a linear coordination environment are very close to those in 1 and 2. Ag-N bond distances in a tri-coordination environment are 2.212(8)-2.315(8) Å, significantly longer than those in a linear coordination geometry, further indicating that the bond distance of the metal-ligated ligand is closely related to its coordination geometry.

elements.content: Complexes 4 and 5 are the isomers of complex 2 and 3, respectively. In 4, Cu−N bond distances in a linear and in tri-coordination environment are 1.907(19)−1.948(17) and 1.947(17)−1.998(17) Å, respectively, and Cu−O bond distances in a tri-coordination geometry are 2.111(13)−2.267(13) Å. Both the bond distances of Cu−N and Cu−O are much different from those of 1.913(3)−1.920(3) (Cu−N) and 2.201(3) and 2.625(4) Å (Cu−O) reported in [{Cu2(2,4‘-Hbipy)4}Mo18As2O62]. It was noted that the successful synthesis of 4 indicates that the atom connectivity in 2 was unambiguously established, although the quality of the crystal was insufficient to permit a detailed structural analysis. In 5, the Cu−N bond distances of 1.904(10) Å in a linear coordination environment are comparable to those in 4 and significantly shorter than that of 1.971(10)−2.052(10) Å in a tri-coordination environment.
elements.clean_text: Complexes 4 and 5 are the isomers of complex 2 and 3, respectively. In 4, Cu-N bond distances in a linear and in tri-coordination environment are 1.907(19)-1.948(17) and 1.947(17)-1.998(17) Å, respectively, and Cu-O bond distances in a tri-coordination geometry are 2.111(13)-2.267(13) Å. Both the bond distances of Cu-N and Cu-O are much different from those of 1.913(3)-1.920(3) (Cu-N) and 2.201(3) and 2.625(4) Å (Cu-O) reported in [{Cu2(2,4‘-Hbipy)4}Mo18As2O62]. It was noted that the successful synthesis of 4 indicates that the atom connectivity in 2 was unambiguously established, although the quality of the crystal was insufficient to permit a detailed structural analysis. In 5, the Cu-N bond distances of 1.904(10) Å in a linear coordination environment  are comparable to those in 4 and significantly shorter than that of 1.971(10)-2.052(10) Å in a tri-coordination environment.

elements.content: Role of Anion in the Assembly of Cyclic Structure. The 2,4‘-bipy ligand, owing to its structural character, often coordinates with two metal atoms in an angle of 60° (Scheme A). Such a coordination mode means 2,4‘-bipy−metal complexes seldom form cyclic structures as demonstrated in the acyclic structures of its Cu(I), Co(II), Cd(II), and Ag(I) complexes. Unambiguously, the formation of a cyclic structure in the present work is attributed to the role of the anion. On the basis of the structures of 1−5, it was found that the charge of the Keggin anion is a key factor to control the ring size of the cyclic structure (as shown in 1 and 2), while the coordination of the Keggin anion to the metal center contributes to the formation of the cyclic structure (as shown in the complexes of 1−3). Clearly, the latter case favoring the formation of a cyclic structure is attributed to the fact that the coordination of the anion to the metal center can effectively prevent the metal ion and ligand from forming the coordination polymer as shown in complexes 1 to 5 and Ag(2,4‘-bipy)X (X = NO3 -, ClO4 -). It must be mentioned that the contribution of the anion to the formation of the cyclic structure in this system is based on the flexible coordination mode of the metal ion; without diverse coordination modes of the metal ion, such as two- and four-coordination modes in 1 (Figure ) and two- and three-coordination modes in 2 (Figure ), it is difficult for the rigid ligand and metal ion to form six- and four-membered ring structures as shown in complexes 1 and 2, respectively. In principle, in addition to forming the six- (Scheme B) and four-membered ring structures (Scheme C), it is possible for Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) and 2,4‘-bipy to form other two types of cyclic structures, a molecular dinuclear loop (Scheme D) and triangle (Scheme E), on the basis of the diverse coordination mode of the Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) ion. In fact, the molecular dinuclear loop, as a building unit, existing in complex 3 (or 5) clearly shows this possibility. Notably, although in comparison with the former three, the Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) ion in the molecular triangle is located in a relatively stable coordination geometry; it is difficult to obtain such a cyclic structure when the Keggin anion was used. The failure of obtaining a molecular triangle may be attributed to the Keggin anion disadvantageously forming such a type of cyclic structure, which, to some extent, also indicates the role of the anion in the assembly of a cyclic structure.
elements.clean_text: Role of Anion in the Assembly of Cyclic Structure. The 2,4‘-bipy ligand, owing to its structural character, often coordinates with two metal atoms in an angle of 60° (Scheme A). Such a coordination mode means 2,4‘-bipy-metal complexes seldom form cyclic structures as demonstrated in the acyclic structures of its Cu(I), Co(II), Cd(II), and Ag(I) complexes. Unambiguously, the formation of a cyclic structure in the present work is attributed to the role of the anion. On the basis of the structures of 1-5, it was found that the charge of the Keggin anion is a key factor to control the ring size of the cyclic structure (as shown in 1 and 2), while the coordination of the Keggin anion to the metal center contributes to the formation of the cyclic structure (as shown in the complexes of 1-3). Clearly, the latter case favoring the formation of a cyclic structure is attributed to the fact that the coordination of the anion to the metal center can effectively prevent the metal ion and ligand from forming the coordination polymer as shown in complexes 1 to 5 and Ag(2,4‘-bipy)X (X = NO3 -, ClO4 -). It must be mentioned that the contribution of the anion to the formation of the cyclic structure in this system is based on the flexible coordination mode of the metal ion; without diverse coordination modes of the metal ion, such as two- and four-coordination modes in 1 (Figure ) and two- and three-coordination modes in 2 (Figure ), it is difficult for the rigid ligand and metal ion to form six- and four-membered ring structures as shown in complexes 1 and 2, respectively. In principle, in addition to forming the six- (Scheme B) and four-membered ring structures (Scheme C), it is possible for Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) and 2,4‘-bipy to form other two types of cyclic structures, a molecular dinuclear loop (Scheme D) and triangle (Scheme E), on the basis of the diverse coordination mode of the Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) ion. In fact, the molecular dinuclear loop, as a building unit, existing in complex 3 (or 5) clearly shows this possibility. Notably, although in comparison with the former three, the Ag(I) (or Cu(I)) ion in the molecular triangle is located in a relatively stable coordination geometry; it is difficult to obtain such a cyclic structure when the Keggin anion was used. The failure of obtaining a molecular triangle may be attributed to the Keggin anion disadvantageously forming such a type of cyclic structure, which, to some extent, also indicates the role of the anion in the assembly of a cyclic structure.

elements.content: Coordination Mode of the 2,4‘-bipy Ligand to Metal Ions (A) and Different Types of Cyclic Structures Assembled (B, C) as well as Possibly Assembled (D, E) by Silver(I) Ion and 2,4‘-bipy Ligand
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination Mode of the 2,4‘-bipy Ligand to Metal Ions (A) and Different Types of Cyclic Structures Assembled (B, C) as well as Possibly Assembled (D, E) by Silver(I) Ion and 2,4‘-bipy Ligand

elements.content: Anions are known to be an important factor that affects the structures of coordination polymers, including Ag(I)- and Cu(I)-based coordination polymers. As one may note, however, the anion effect was used to control the dimensionality and/or topology of the coordination polymer in most cases. In contrast, such an effect is seldom considered in the assembly of the cyclic structure. In this work, we, based on the same metal ion and rigid ligand, have successfully assembled different types of cyclic structures, showing clearly the role of the anion in the assembly of a cyclic structure. Investigation of their structural differences reveals that the controllability and adjustability of the anion in the formation of a cyclic structure in a rigid ligand system is closely related to the coordination of the anion to the metal center and the flexible coordination mode of the metal ion; that is, in a rigid ligand system, the coordination of the anion to the metal center favors the formation of a cyclic structure, while the flexible coordination mode of a metal ion favors the formation of different types of cyclic structures. Thus, the present work would be helpful for the rational design and assembly of different types of cyclic structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Anions are known to be an important factor that affects the structures of coordination polymers, including Ag(I)- and Cu(I)-based coordination polymers. As one may note, however, the anion effect was used to control the dimensionality and/or topology of the coordination polymer in most cases. In contrast, such an effect is seldom considered in the assembly of the cyclic structure. In this work, we, based on the same metal ion and rigid ligand, have successfully assembled different types of cyclic structures, showing clearly the role of the anion in the assembly of a cyclic structure. Investigation of their structural differences reveals that the controllability and adjustability of the anion in the formation of a cyclic structure in a rigid ligand system is closely related to the coordination of the anion to the metal center and the flexible coordination mode of the metal ion; that is, in a rigid ligand system, the coordination of the anion to the metal center favors the formation of a cyclic structure, while the flexible coordination mode of a metal ion favors the formation of different types of cyclic structures. Thus, the present work would be helpful for the rational design and assembly of different types of cyclic structures.

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses. (a) [Ag 3 (2,4‘-bipy) 3 PMo 12 O 40 ] (1) A mixture of H3PMo12O40 (0.31 g, 0.17 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1.0 mol L-1 NaOH, and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 160 °C and held at that temperature for 8000 min, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Brown-yellow polyhedron crystals of 1 were collected in 90.3% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 1, C30H24Ag3N6O40PMo12:  C, 13.78; H, 0.93; N, 3.21. Found:  C, 13.27; H, 1.06; N, 3.36 IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3448s, 2975m, 1636s, 1473m, 1428m, 1061s, 964s, 884s, 801s, 503w.

(b) [Ag 4 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 SiW 12 O 40 ] (2). A mixture of H4SiW12O40 (0.36 g, 0.13 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 160 °C and held at that temperature for 8000 min, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Pale yellow polyhedron crystals of 2 were collected in 76.2% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 2, C40H32Ag4N8O40SiW12:  C, 12.22; H, 0.82; N, 2.85. Found:  C, 11.46; H, 0.93; N, 2.76. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 2926w, 1618m, 1467w, 1410w, 1014w, 973m, 924s, 882w, 802s, 534m.

(c) [Ag 3 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 ]PW 12 O 40 (3). Complex 3 was prepared in a similar way as illustrated for 1. Pale-yellow block crystals of 3 were collected in 80% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 3, C40H32Ag3N8O40PW12:  C, 12.55; H, 0.84; N, 2.93; Found:  C, 11.75; H, 0.90; N, 2.79. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3447s, 2962w, 1614m, 1596m, 1544w, 1473m, 1419m, 1079s, 975s, 893s, 811s, 510m.

(d) [Cu 4 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 SiW 12 O 40 ] (4). A mixture of H4SiW12O40 (0.36 g, 0.13 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 180 °C and held at that temperature for 5000 min, then cooled to 120 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Red block crystals of 4 were collected in 56.2% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 4, C40H32Cu4N8O40SiW12:  C, 12.80; H, 0.86; N, 2.99; Found:  C, 12.45; H, 0.94; N, 2.75. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3442s, 2925w, 1617s, 1473w, 1416m, 1011m, 973m, 921s, 883s, 797s, 533m..

(e) [Cu 3 (2,4‘-bipy) 4 ]PW 12 O 40 (5). A mixture of H3PW12O40 (0.33 g, 0.17 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3−4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 180 °C and held at that temperature for 5000 min, then cooled to 120 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Red stick crystals of 5 were collected in 53.8% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 5, C40H32Cu3N8O40PW12:  C, 13.01; H, 0.87; N, 3.03; Found:  C, 12.68; H, 1.02, N, 2.95. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1):  3446s, 1618s, 1595w, 1541w, 1471s, 1435m, 1418s, 1220w, 1079s, 977s, 893s, 814s, 667w, 596w, 521m.

The container was heated to 180 °C and held at that temperature for 5000 min, then cooled to 120 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1. Red block crystals of 4 were collected in 56.2% yield based on 2,4‘-bipy. Anal. Calcd for 4, C40H32Cu4N8O40SiW12: C, 12.80; H, 0.86; N, 2.99; Found: C, 12.45; H, 0.94; N, 2.75. IR spectra (KBr, cm-1): 3442s, 2925w, 1617s, 1473w, 1416m, 1011m, 973m, 921s, 883s, 797s, 533m.. 

 (e) [Cu  3  (2,4‘-bipy)  4  ]PW  12  O  40   (5). A mixture of H3PW12O40 (0.33 g, 0.17 mmol), 2,4‘-bipy (0.08 g, 0.5 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.12 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was adjusted to approximately pH = 3-4 with 1 mol L-1 NaOH and then transferred and sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 180 °C and held at that temperature for 5000 min, then cooled to 120 °C at a rate of 5 °C h-1, and held for 2000 min, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C h-1.
